<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 177, 163, 191]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 197, 349, 212]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 177, 865, 212]]<|/det|>
0625/23 October/November 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[776, 217, 863, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 237, 560, 280]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 297, 371, 312]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 327, 860, 395]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 409, 850, 440]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 438, 848, 453]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 465, 529, 481]]<|/det|>
## Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 494, 728, 509]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 509, 445, 523]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 523, 343, 537]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 537, 599, 552]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 67, 667, 87]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 94, 210, 112]]<|/det|>
balance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 120, 128, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 120, 361, 138]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 470, 589, 489]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 500, 445, 517]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 527, 680, 545]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 570, 831, 588]]<|/det|>
Which equation shows the relationship between the weight \(W\) and the mass \(m\) of an object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 603, 210, 623]]<|/det|>

<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 878, 101]]<|/det|>
A toy train P of mass \(0.50\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling along a straight track with a velocity of \(3.0\mathrm{m / s}\). It collides with a stationary train Q of mass \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\). The two trains then stick together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 110, 455, 129]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 136, 128, 154]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 186, 603, 204]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 255, 504, 272]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 280, 803, 348]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 359, 876, 392]]<|/det|>
When the temperature of the thermometer rises, the changes produced cause the liquid thread to move to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 402, 672, 420]]<|/det|>
Why does this happen when the temperature of the thermometer rises?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 429, 128, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 429, 423, 447]]<|/det|>
Gases contract and liquids expand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 455, 128, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 455, 418, 472]]<|/det|>
Gases contract and solids expand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 480, 126, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 480, 406, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 504, 128, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 504, 406, 522]]<|/det|>
Liquids expand more than solids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 101, 85]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 761, 85]]<|/det|> A sealed metal box contains a fixed mass of air. The sides of the box are insulated. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 94, 640, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 215, 870, 247]]<|/det|> A scientist investigates the thermal conductivity of air. She measures how quickly thermal energy passes between the top and bottom of the box. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 257, 549, 275]]<|/det|> Which row gives the correct procedure and conclusion? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 285, 688, 409]]<|/det|>
procedureconclusion
Aheat bottom surfaceair is a good thermal conductor
Bheat bottom surfaceair is a poor thermal conductor
Cheat top surfaceair is a good thermal conductor
Dheat top surfaceair is a poor thermal conductor
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 434, 99, 452]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 434, 876, 481]]<|/det|> In a cold country, the ground is covered in snow. There is a pile of black sand outdoors and its temperature is the same as that of the snow. A man sprinkles a thin layer of this sand over the snow. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 491, 609, 510]]<|/det|> Why does the black sand help to melt the snow during the day? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 518, 128, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 518, 599, 536]]<|/det|> Any thermal energy still left in the sand will melt the snow. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 545, 128, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 545, 715, 562]]<|/det|> The black sand is a good absorber of the infrared radiation from the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 570, 128, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 570, 574, 588]]<|/det|> The black sand is a good conductor of thermal energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 594, 128, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 594, 561, 612]]<|/det|> The black sand lowers the melting point of the snow.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 99, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 67, 707, 87]]<|/det|>
A plastic rod is rubbed with a dry cloth. The rod becomes positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 96, 467, 115]]<|/det|>
Why has the rod become positively charged?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 123, 128, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 123, 331, 141]]<|/det|>
It has gained electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 148, 128, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 148, 327, 166]]<|/det|>
It has gained neutrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 173, 128, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 173, 304, 191]]<|/det|>
It has lost electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 198, 128, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 198, 301, 215]]<|/det|>
It has lost neutrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 240, 101, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 240, 875, 273]]<|/det|>
There is a current of 3.0A in a resistor for time \(t\). During time \(t\), a charge of 120 C flows through the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 284, 235, 301]]<|/det|>
What is time \(t\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 310, 128, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 310, 260, 327]]<|/det|>
0.025 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 335, 128, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 335, 205, 352]]<|/det|>
0.025 s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 359, 128, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 359, 235, 377]]<|/det|>
40 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 384, 128, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 384, 180, 402]]<|/det|>
40 s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 425, 101, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 425, 702, 444]]<|/det|>
Identical resistors are connected together to form arrangements X, Y and Z.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 451, 868, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 559, 870, 579]]<|/det|>
What is the correct order of the resistances of the arrangements from the largest to the smallest?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 588, 128, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 588, 238, 606]]<|/det|>
X \(\rightarrow\) Y \(\rightarrow\) Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 615, 128, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 615, 238, 632]]<|/det|>
Y \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 640, 128, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 640, 238, 658]]<|/det|>
Z \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 666, 128, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 666, 238, 684]]<|/det|>
Z \(\rightarrow\) Y \(\rightarrow\) X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 69, 99, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 69, 876, 102]]<|/det|>
Resistors of resistance \(1.0\Omega\), \(2.0\Omega\) and \(3.0\Omega\) are connected in parallel across the terminals of a cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 112, 332, 129]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 139, 128, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 139, 448, 156]]<|/det|>
The currents in the resistors are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 164, 126, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 164, 757, 181]]<|/det|>
The sum of the currents in the three resistors is equal to the current in the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 190, 123, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 189, 875, 221]]<|/det|>
The sum of the potential differences (p.d.'s) across the resistors is equal to the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 229, 126, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 229, 875, 260]]<|/det|>
The potential difference across the \(3.0\Omega\) resistor is greater than the potential difference across the other two resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 286, 101, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 285, 875, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 329, 875, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 526, 292, 542]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 553, 128, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 553, 228, 570]]<|/det|>
thermistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 579, 128, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 579, 220, 596]]<|/det|>
relay coil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 604, 128, 621]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 101, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 677, 87]]<|/det|> A step-up transformer produces a \(60 \text{V}\) a.c. output from a \(12 \text{V}\) a.c. input. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 97, 437, 115]]<|/det|> There are 50 turns on the secondary coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 125, 477, 144]]<|/det|> How many turns are there on the primary coil? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 152, 128, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 152, 160, 170]]<|/det|> 5 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 152, 285, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[291, 152, 326, 170]]<|/det|> 10 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 152, 445, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 152, 485, 170]]<|/det|> 50 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[586, 152, 606, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 152, 656, 170]]<|/det|> 250 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 195, 102, 214]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 195, 777, 214]]<|/det|> An a.c. generator contains a coil that rotates at a rate of 4500 revolutions per minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 224, 490, 243]]<|/det|> What is the frequency of the alternating current? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 250, 128, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 250, 160, 268]]<|/det|> 1.25 Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 250, 288, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[291, 250, 351, 268]]<|/det|> 75 Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 250, 445, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 250, 520, 268]]<|/det|> 150 Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[586, 250, 606, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 250, 688, 268]]<|/det|> 4500 Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 293, 102, 312]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 293, 646, 312]]<|/det|> Why are some radioactive sources stored in boxes made from lead? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 320, 128, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 320, 574, 339]]<|/det|> Lead absorbs emissions from the radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 345, 126, 364]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 345, 544, 364]]<|/det|> Lead decreases the half-life of radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 370, 126, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 370, 539, 389]]<|/det|> Lead increases the half-life of radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 395, 128, 414]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 395, 554, 414]]<|/det|> Lead repels emissions from the radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 438, 102, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 438, 425, 457]]<|/det|> The diagram represents a neutral atom. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 462, 620, 609]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 616, 561, 635]]<|/det|> Which row identifies each type of particle in the diagram? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 644, 564, 785]]<|/det|>
○\(\bigcirc\)\(\bullet\)
Aelectronneutronproton
Belectronprotonneutron
Cneutronelectronproton
Dprotonelectronneutron

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 69, 99, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 69, 876, 102]]<|/det|>
A thin metal foil is placed in a vacuum. \(\alpha\) -particles are fired at the foil and most go straight through. A very small proportion of the \(\alpha\) -particles are deflected through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 112, 405, 129]]<|/det|>
What does this provide evidence for?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 141, 128, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 141, 351, 158]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles are very small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 166, 124, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 166, 482, 183]]<|/det|>
There are negative electrons in each atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 191, 126, 209]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 191, 435, 208]]<|/det|>
There is a tiny nucleus in each atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 216, 128, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 216, 408, 233]]<|/det|>
There are neutrons in each atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 258, 101, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 256, 774, 275]]<|/det|>
The background count rate measured by a radiation counter is 40 counts per minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 286, 834, 304]]<|/det|>
With the counter close to a radioactive source, the counter reading is 960 counts per minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 315, 425, 333]]<|/det|>
The half-life of the source is 20 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 344, 453, 361]]<|/det|>
What is the counter reading one hour later?
